RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE PORTSMOUTH GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0    INTRODUCTION
                                                                                    
The United States Enrichment Company (USEC) has prepared an updated Risk Management Plan [RMP] for the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant (PORTS). The RMP is in accordance with the requirements set forth in Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations 40 CFR Part 68. The PORTS plant is subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP requirements.

2.0    MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATION

USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public, and protects the environment.  In order to meet these commitments, USEC has issued an operations policy manual which states, in part:  USEC is ultimately responsible for, and is committed to safe operations, maintenance, design, fabrication, and testing of the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant, and is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public, protects the environment and provides for the common defense and security.

Program and staff organizations are established for safety, safeguards and quality, and environmental, safety, and health with sufficient resources to support the line organization in safe operation of the plant.

3.0    GENERAL DESCRIPTION

3.1    Facility Description and Location

The gaseous diffusion plant facilities have been transitioned into cold shutdown (CSD) status.  Under CSD for DOE, USEC is deactivating equipment and removing lube oil, pyranol oils, and uranium deposit holdups in the process equipment in advance of eventual decontamination and decommissioning (D&D).  In addition to D&D, USEC performs a wide variety of services for the U.S. Government, which includes, processing out-of-specification uranium, and providing infrastructure support services such as security, firefighting, water distribu

tion, sewage treatment, electrical distribution, and maintenance for the gaseous diffusion plant.

The Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant is located at 39A?00'30" N. latitude and 83A?00'00" W. longitude measured at the center of the plant, on an approximately 3,708-acre Federally-owned reservation in Pike County, Ohio.  The site is generally in a rural area, and was previously farmland and the watershed for several intermittent streams.  PORTS occupies approximately 650 acres within the Controlled Access Area about 1.5 miles east of U.S. Route 23 and 2 miles south of State Route 32, and 2 miles east of the Scioto River.  The entire facility is owned by the United States Department of Energy (DOE).

USEC leases and operates a portion of the plant.  The portion of PORTS leased by USEC contains more than 120 buildings with a total floor space of about 14.2 million square feet.  Three large enrichment process buildings constitute approximately 38 percent of the plants' total floor space.  There are also cooling towers, electrical switchyards, and several support operations structures, including sewage and liquid effluent treatment plants, decontamination and recovery operations, coal and ash-handling facilities, water treatment facilities, steam plant, maintenance operations, laboratories, fluorine facilities, and air plants.

Buildings, facilities and areas not leased by USEC are owned and operated by DOE.

This RMP applies only to facilities leased by USEC.

3.2    Regulated Substances

Chlorine, fluorine, and anhydrous hydrogen fluoride are the only substances listed in 40 CFR 68.130 which are present in quantities exceeding the threshold quantity.  Chlorine, fluorine, and anhydrous hydrogen fluoride are used in three separate processes and are managed in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 PSM program.

3.3    Use of Regulated Substances

3.3.1    Process One - Chlorine

Raw water is taken from well fields, treated and supplied to PORTS for numerous uses.  A

portion of the water is filtered and post-disinfected, using chlorine, and used to supply sanitary water, fire system water, cooling water, and other uses.  Raw water treatment takes place at the X-611 Water Treatment Plant which is located to the north of the plant.  The sanitary water treatment process is similar to other water treatment plants throughout the United States that use chlorine to disinfect the water for sanitary purposes. 

The chlorine, provided in 1-ton cylinders, has a maximum administrative limit of three filled chlorine cylinders at any one time.  This quantity is in excess of the threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.  A typical working inventory is two cylinders attached to the system manifold.  The third container, if present, would be in an unconnected storage position adjacent to the in-use cylinders.  All three container positions are inside a building with a vehicle door to accommodate deliveries. 

3.3.2    Process Two - Fluorine and Hydrogen Fluoride

The X-342 fluorine generation complex produces fluorine from HF.  The HF is received in 850 pound cylinders, with up to two cylinders connected to the fluorine generation system inside a heated cabinet within the X-342 building.  Additional cylinders are staged in a separate room (Process 3).  The HF is electrolytically disassociated into hydrogen, which is discharged to the atmosphere, and fluorine, which is stored in a set of tanks enclosed in a third room.  The fluorine is used as needed in the maintenance of the uranium enrichment equipment.

The X-342 fluorine complex has the potential to release up to 1,290 pounds of fluorine or 1,700 pounds of HF.  The HF has a physical limit of two filled cylinders (nominally 850 pounds of HF per container) in use.  The fluorine has an administrative limit of 1,290 pounds.  Both these quantities are in excess of the threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.

3.3.3    Process Three - Hydrogen Fluoride

The X-342 fluorine generation stores HF for the pr

oduction of fluorine.  In the original RMP, this was included as part of Process 2 above.  During the last RMP inspection, the senior inspector advised PORTS that the storage of the HF cylinders in a room adjacent to the fluorine generation needed to be considered a separate process.

The HF is received in 850 pound cylinders.  Additional cylinders are staged in a separate room from the fluorine generation process within the same building.  Individual cylinders are moved to the feed cabinet as needed.  The X-342 fluorine generation complex has an administrative limit of eight filled cylinders staged for use (including the two cylinders actually in use).  Stored cylinders, holding a maximum of 5,100 pounds (six cylinders in storage) of HF are adjacent to, but not connected to, each other.

4.0    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

PORTS five year history exhibits a chemical release performance of no significant or threshold quantity release of chlorine, fluorine, or HF.  Minor releases can occur during routine operations and maintenance activities, but have not resulted in significant personnel exposure or environmental impacts.

5.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

USEC has addressed release potentials and risks in safety analysis documents and by the use of management systems.  Details of these mitigative actions to ensure safe operating conditions can be found in "Application For United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission Certification Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant Safety Analysis Report" and in 29 CFR 1910.119 PHAs for the X-342 Fluorine Generation Complex and the X-611E Water Treatment Facility.

These site-level systems apply uniformly for the management of structures, systems, programs, and components that pertain to an RMP covered process and related activities.

5.1    Systems

The chlorine feed facility is equipped with container-mounted vacuum regulators which reduce the pressure of the chlorine from the vapor pressure

of the liquid chlorine in the container to a partial vacuum.  Loss of vacuum for any reason causes the vacuum-regulating valve to close the gas supply, minimizing the release in the event of a break in the manifold.  The chlorine feed facility is equipped with chlorine detectors which provide alarms to plant personnel in the event of a release.

Hydrogen fluoride detectors (Pyr-A-Larms) are located:  (1) in the X-342A Hydrogen Fluoride Storage Room, (2) in the X-342A Vaporizer Room above the hydrogen fluoride vaporizer and in the heated cabinet, and (3) above each of the three fluorine storage tanks in the X-342B Building (the reaction of fluorine and wet air will produce hydrogen fluoride).  If hydrogen fluoride is detected, an alarm is actuated in the X-342A Control Room and at the affected facility.  The Pyr-A-Larms are checked monthly by I&C Maintenance.

Twelve hydrogen fluoride detectors and ten fluorine detectors are installed in the following areas of the X-342A Facility: (1) one each above each generator, (2) one fluorine detector above the surge drum, (3) one hydrogen fluoride detector above instrument transmitters in the generator room, (4) one hydrogen fluoride detector in the Vaporizer Room, (5), one hydrogen fluoride detector above valving in the high bay mezzanine, (6) one each above the Q circuit valve in the Trap Room, (7) one each above and between the sodium fluoride traps, (8) one each above headers in the Trap Room, (9) one each above the filters in the Trap Room, and (10) one each above pumps in the Trap Room.  If hydrogen fluoride and/or fluorine is detected, an alarm is actuated in the X-342 Control Room and in the affected area.  The detectors are calibrated quarterly.

In addition to gas detection systems, it is expected that minor leaks or conditions that may lead to leaks would be detected by Operations personnel during routine operations, shift walkdowns/turnover activities, or routine operational status checks.

Manually operated gas r

elease alarms are located throughout the X-342 Building.  Activation of these alarms will result in the sounding of the building evacuation siren.

Hydrogen fluoride "smoke" detectors are located inside the heated cabinet, above the hydrogen fluoride cylinder storage rack and above the hydrogen fluoride vaporizer.  The detector heads are connected in series, and a failure of any one will sound the alarm.

An emergency shutdown system exists to protect fluorine generation equipment and to isolate the piping and storage tanks.  This system can be activated manually whenever building personnel decide that alarm conditions warrant system shutdown.

5.2    Procedures

Plant procedures are prepared in accordance with the requirements of a formal procedure system.  The procedure program includes the development, review and approval, revision process, distribution, and procedure configuration management.  Specific procedures for the operation and maintenance of PHA systems and handling of the chemicals covered under PSM are managed within this procedure system.

5.3    Training

Employee training is conducted by a dedicated training organization.  Personnel who operate, maintain, manage, handle, and have emergency response duties for chemicals covered under the PSM are adequately trained for the particular chemical system or related activity.  The training program for such individuals shall be based upon a systems approach to training.

5.4    Maintenance and Inspection

The engineering group, in conjunction with the specific facility maintenance organizations and the manufacturerA!A?s recommendations, develops maintenance and inspection requirements and criteria for chemical systems.  These chemical safety requirements are based on PSM program requirements for the particular system.

Maintenance of chemical systems is performed in accordance with the facility maintenance programs that include the PSM Mechanical Integrity Program for systems covered under PSM.

Maintenance work pack

ages are prepared to provide the necessary technical and safety guidance for maintenance activities.

5.5    Preventive Maintenance

Manufacturer's recommendations are used as guides for preventive maintenance on specific chemical systems and equipment.  Equipment installed or maintenance services provided by contractors for chemicals systems are tested and inspected by the contractor required by the contract for that project.  There has been no contractor work on the covered PSM processes since the original RMP was submitted in 1999.  PORTS personnel perform independent inspection and testing for systems covered under PSM.

5.6    Quality Considerations

Independent overview of maintenance activities on chemical hardware is address by the Quality Assurance and Configuration Management programs, as applicable.  These independent programs include:

Procurement Quality Requirements
Construction Inspection
Testing and Pre-Operational Inspection
Pressure Vessel Inspection
Crane Inspection
Operational Readiness Review and Pre-Startup Review Programs
Plant Operations Review Committee

5.7    Configuration Management (CM)

The CM program is applicable to chemical systems.  The plant CM Program includes an organizational structure and administrative process and controls to ensure that accurate, current design documentation is maintained that matches the plant physical configuration.

In accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119(i), a pre-startup safety review is performed for new or modified facilities when the change is significant enough to require a change to process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review is an independent review to address the readiness of the system hardware, associated hazard controls, personnel (including required training), and procedures.  If the change does not require a change to process safety information, a pre-startup safety review is not performed.  There have been no new or significantly modified PSM process or facilities; thus, no pre-startup revi

ews have been performed recently.

6.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

PORTS maintains a written Emergency Plan.  The Emergency Plan provides an overall description of the comprehensive site-wide emergency preparedness program and is based in large measure on the emergency preparedness policies, procedures, and practices that have been successfully used at PORTS for over 40 years.  This program has been established to manage and respond in a consistent and integrated way to accidents or other emergency situations that may occur at the site.  The structure of this program is intended to ensure that the consequences of emergencies are promptly mitigated and that the health and safety of the public, personnel on the surrounding Department of Energy reservation, and plant personnel are protected, regardless of the cause or nature of the emergency.  The Emergency Management organization is responsible for maintaining and updating the Emergency Plan as appropriate.

6.1    Organization

The Emergency Response Organization (ERO) is responsible for taking immediate mitigative and corrective actions to minimize the consequences of an incident to workers, public health and safety, and the environment.  The ERO is staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week with trained personnel who respond to events and are required to participate in formal training, drills, and exercises.  The initial ERO consists of appropriate shift personnel with the PSS or designee as Incident Commander.  Upon classification of the emergency, the PSS becomes the Crisis Manager (CM) and maintains overall control of the plant during the emergency until relieved.  Once the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) is operational, the General Manager, or designee, relieves the PSS as CM and the overall control of the emergency shifts from the PSS to the CM. 

The ERO is divided into functional groups as follows:
1.  Field ERO,
2.  EOC cadre, and
3.  Joint Public Information Center (JPIC)

Capability for initial site-level respo

nse prior to EOC activation is provided by the following:
1.  PSS personnel,
2.  Protective force personnel,
3.  Fire services personnel,
4.  Emergency squad personnel, and
5.  Local emergency director

6.2    ERO Actions

In the event of an emergency, such as a toxic chemical release, PSS personnel take the following actions:

Ensure the safety of the plant and the general public
Ensure safe operations/activities of the plant
Classify the emergency and makes required notifications, if necessary
Perform assessment actions
Perform any other emergency actions as appropriate


6.3    Emergency Response Equipment

Emergency response equipment at PORTS includes detectors and alarms, communications equipment, personnel protection equipment and spill/release containment and cleanup equipment.  Container patches and plugs specifically designed for the use on types of containers used at PORTS are available to the Plant Emergency Squad.

6.4    Training

A formal training program, which includes classroom-type training (lectures, seminars), practical applications (tabletop drills, functional drills, and exercises), and self-study programs has been developed for the ERO and support personnel.  The ERO receives training commensurate with assigned positions.  This training program ensures the continued emergency management training of persons who may respond/participate during a plant emergency.  Specialized emergency management training is provided and includes but is not limited to the following categories of topics:

Emergency Management Overview
Operational Facility Training
Credible Emergencies
Emergency Management Drill and Exercise Participation
Emergency Notifications/Communications
Operational Facility Support
Emergency Response Activities

6.5    Drills and Exercises

Emergency management drills and exercises are conducted to develop, maintain and test the response capabilities of emergency personnel, facilities, equipment, procedures and training.

A drill is a supervised instruc

tion session that develops, tests, or maintains a specific emergency response capability using a limited scope scenario.  Drills are held quarterly and involve decision-making and actions by participating personnel to simulate emergency conditions but do not involve offsite response personnel. 

An exercise is a training session that tests the integrated capability of all or most of the basic elements existing within the emergency plan.  Exercises use scenarios that are wider in scope than drills and may involve offsite response personnel and agencies.  Plant personnel plan and conduct biennial exercises.

6.6    Public Warning System

The public warning system, consisting of outdoor warning sirens and emergency alert systems announcements, is used to provide emergency notification.  Operations testing of the public warning system is conducted monthly.

6.7    Coordination With Off-site Organizations

Mutual aid agreements, memorandums of understanding, and letters of agreement have been entered into with offsite groups to provide assistance in the event of an emergency.  These support services encompass areas such as medical assistance, fire control, evacuation, ambulance services, and law enforcement.

The Emergency Management organization coordinates required emergency planning activities with local and state agencies including the Ohio Emergency Management Agency and Pike, Scioto, and Ross County Local Emergency Planning Committees.  Emergency planning is also coordinated with DOE.

7.0    EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION PLAN

USEC manages operational safety with an Employee Participation Plan that involves personnel on plant-site.  The Employee Participation Plan expresses expectations of the plant population support and participation, and the individual's roles and responsibilities.  The Plan involves personnel represented by organized labor, salary employees, and subcontractors.  The Employee Participation Plan, initially created with the Union Local Safety and Health Represen

tatives in 1994, is based upon the 29 CFR 1910.119 elements and supported by plant policies and procedures.  The Employee Participation Plan is applied by formal plant implementation procedures, e.g., reporting unsafe activities, emergency response expectations, and configuration management controls.




8.0    INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS

USEC conducts incident and event investigations to protect employees, public health and safety, the environment, and national security interests.  Incident investigations are conducted in accordance with formal procedures.  If a large scale event were to occur, a special investigation team may be appointed to investigate the incident.  Appropriate notification of an incident is by the specific program management and regulatory requirements.  Notification is performed in accordance with formal procedures.

As part of this program, abnormal events are identified, reported, and investigated.  This includes identification, categorization of the event and analysis to determine the root cause and its effect. The corrective actions developed as a result of the investigation are entered into a commitment management database, which is a dedicated database used to track and trend corrective actions and plant commitments. This database also facilitates management's review of the corrective actions and plant commitment.

9.0    COMPLIANCE AUDITS

The Quality Assurance Plan (QAP) includes an audit system which was established for Quality and Augmented Quality items and other activities and services within the scope of the QAP.  The audit systems are in accordance with Basic Requirement 18 and Supplement 18S-1 of NQA-1 (1989).  This system establishes planned and periodic audits to verify the compliance and effectiveness of the QAP in meeting quality requirements.

Independent internal audits of selected aspects of operational activities are performed with a frequency commensurate with their safety significance and in a manner as to assure that audits of

activities within the scope of the QAP are completed within the specified time periods.  Audit reports are managed as described in the Recordkeeping and Document Control program descriptions found in other RMP sections.

Corrective actions and issues resulting from audits, investigations, and regulatory sources are addressed by the Corrective Action management system discussed in this document.  These audits and any corrective actions are processed by existing plant programs that include RMP elements and requirements.

The most recent compliance audit was conducted by Ohio EPA personnel, under contract to the federal EPA.  The audit cited no violations of the RMP requirements, but advised PORTS to split the HF storage into a separate process from the fluorine generation at the next RMP update.  The senior auditor also advised PORTS to label empty HF cylinders in the same or nearby areas as "EMPTY" for the benefit of emergency responders.

10.0      PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

USEC Government Services has applied for Voluntary Protection Program status and anticipates planning for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration onsite evaluation summer 2009.
